The six were banned from all football stadiums for the duration of their trial.<ref name="TK1"/><ref>The Turkish press accused the security, media and PSG club of attempting to cover up the injuries.</ref><ref name="TK2">{{Cite news| title =Lies, damned lies, Paris statistics| url =http://www.turkishdailynews.com.tr/archives.php?id=22416| publisher =[[Turkish Daily News]]| date =19 March 2001| accessdate =2006-10-21| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070930171317/http://www.turkishdailynews.com.tr/archives.php?id=22416| archivedate =30 September 2007| df =dmy-all}}</ref>
On 24 November 2006 a PSG fan was shot and killed by police and another seriously injured during fighting between PSG fans and the police. The violence occurred after PSG lost 4–2 to [[Israeli people|Israeli]] club [[Hapoel Tel Aviv F.C.|Hapoel Tel Aviv]] at the Parc des Prince in a [[UEFA Cup]] match. PSG fans chased a fan of Hapoel Tel Aviv, shouting racist and anti-semitic slogans. A plainclothes police officer who tried to protect the Hapoel fan was attacked, and in the chaos, one fan was shot dead and another seriously injured. In response, the French Interior Minister, [[Nicolas Sarkozy]] held a meeting with the president of the French Football League, Frederic Thiriez to discuss racism and violence in football. The director-general of the French police, Michel Gaudin, insisted that measures against football hooliganism had reduced racist incidents to six that season from nineteen in the previous season. Gaudin also stated that 300 known hooligans could be banned from matches.<ref name="BBC2">{{Cite news| title = France faces up to football hooliganism |url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/6189888.stm | publisher = BBC| date= 27 November 2006 | accessdate = 2007-04-29 | first=Caroline | last=Wyatt}}</ref> The fan who was shot, was linked with the ''Boulogne Boys'', a group of fans who modelled themselves on British hooligans in the 1980s. The group's name comes from the [[Kop of Boulogne]] (KOB), one of the two main home fan stand at the Parc des Princes.
The KOB themselves held a silent memorial march attended by 300 and accused the police office of murdering the fan. They cited bias in the French press who had only given a "one-sided" account of the incident.<ref name="BBC2"/> French President [[Jacques Chirac]] condemned violence that led up to the shooting, stating that he was horrified by the reports of racism and anti-Semitism. French Prime Minister, [[Dominique de Villepin]] called for new, tougher measures to deal with football hooligans. Prosecutors opened an inquiry into the incident, to determine whether the officer involved should face criminal charges.<ref name="BBC5">{{Cite news| title = Chirac condemns football violence |url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/6182414.stm | publisher = BBC| date= 25 November 2006 | accessdate = 2007-04-29}}</ref><ref name="BBC6">{{Cite news| title = Paris fan shot dead by policeman |url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/6179418.stm | publisher = BBC| date= 24 November 2006 | accessdate = 2007-04-29}}</ref> [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-1990-0408-011, FC Carl Zeiss Jena - FC Berlin, Ausschreitungen.jpg|thumb|right |German football hooligans with masked faces in a 1990s match.]]Before a home match against [[FC Sochaux-Montbéliard|Sochaux]] on 4 January 2006, two [[Arab]] youths were punched and kicked by [[white people|white]] fans outside the entrance to the KOB. During the match racist insults were aimed at black players and a PSG player of [[Demographics of India|Indian]] origin, [[Vikash Dhorasoo]] was told to "go sell peanuts in the metro".<ref name="Bay" /> In the recent years, following UK's example, France's legislation has changed, including more and more banning of violent fans from stadiums. The threat of dissolution of fan groups has also tempered the outward rivalry and violence of a number of fans. Known violent fans under ban sentences are to report to the nearest Police station on nights of game, to prove they are not anywhere in proximity to the stadium.
On 11 June 2016, during a Euro 2016 match in [[Marseille]] between Russia and England, violent conflict broke out between the fans and left 35 injured. Both threw numerous items at each other and engaged in physical combat. Even a person who is recording the incident can be seen stomping another person's head.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2016/06/14/new-gopro-style-footage-shows-fan-violence-first-hand/|title=Incredible GoPro-style footage from Russian fan shows Euro 2016 violence with England supporters first-hand|website=The Telegraph|access-date=2016-06-14}}</ref> Because of this, both countries were given a disqualification warning soon later.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-36510550|title=Euro 2016: England and Russia given disqualification warning - BBC News|website=BBC News|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-06-14}}</ref> The match ended with 1-1.
On 16 April 2017, during a match between [[Olympique Lyonnais]] and [[SC Bastia]], supporters of SC Bastia [[pitch invasion|invaded the pitch]] in an attempt to fight Lyonnais players. The match was then postponed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/apr/16/lyon-players-bastia-supporters-invade-pitch|title=Bastia v Lyon abandoned after home fans invade pitch and attack players|first=Guardian|last=sport|date=16 April 2017|website=the Guardian}}</ref>
===Germany=== Some football hooliganism in Germany has been linked to [[neo-Nazism]] and far right groups.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/126040.stm |title=Fears of neo-Nazi return to World Cup |publisher=BBC News |date=3 July 1998 |accessdate=2013-09-01}}</ref> In June 1998, after a [[FIFA World Cup]] match in France between [[Germany national football team|Germany]] and Yugoslavia a French policeman was beaten to the point of brain damage by German fans. Following the incident, German police contacted many of the known 2,000+ German hooligans to warn them they would be arrested if they travelled to upcoming matches in France.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/122057.stm |title=German hooligans warned |publisher=BBC News |date=29 June 1998 |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref> A German fan was arrested in 1998 and charged with attempted murder<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/127767.stm |title=Gendarme attack suspect arrested |publisher=BBC News |date=6 July 1998 |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/144985.stm |title=World Cup policeman out of coma |publisher=BBC News |date=5 August 1998 |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref> and in 1999, four more Germans were convicted in the attack<ref>The main defendant, Andre Zawacki, was found guilty of attempted murder and sentenced to ten years in jail. The other three defendants were convicted of grievous bodily harm and given jail sentences of between six months and three-and-a-half years.</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/511306.stm |title=German football hooligans jailed |publisher=BBC News |date=9 November 1999 |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref> In 2001, Markus Warnecke, the German fan who was accused of leading the attack, was found guilty and jailed for five years and banned from France for ten years, and from all sports facilities for five years.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/1344821.stm |title=German fan jailed for gendarme attack |publisher=BBC News |date=22 May 2001 |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref>
[[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-1990-0407-027, FC Carl Zeiss Jena - FC Berlin 1-1, Ausschreitungen.jpg|thumb|German police prepare for hooliganism by wearing riot gear and using [[police dog]]s.]] In March 2005, German football fans fought with police and rival fans at a [[Exhibition game|friendly match]] between Germany and [[Slovenia national football team|Slovenia]] in [[Celje]], [[Slovenia]], damaging cars and shops, and shouting [[racism|racist]] slogans. The [[German Football Association]] (DFB) apologised for the behaviour. As a result, 52 people were arrested; 40 Germans and 12 Slovenians.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,2144,1531870,00.html |title=German Hooligans Taint Slovenian Friendly |publisher=Dw-world.de |date= |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,2144,1539291,00.html |title=The Specter of Hooliganism Returns |publisher=Dw-world.de |date= |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref> Following a 2–0 defeat to [[Slovakia national football team|Slovakia]] in [[Bratislava]], [[Slovakia]], German hooligans fought with the local police, and six people were injured and two were taken into custody. The DFB again apologised for fans who chanted racist slogans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,2144,1701053,00.html |title=German Hooligans Make Mark in Bratislava |publisher=Dw-world.de |date= |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref>
In June 2006, Germany beat [[Poland national football team|Poland]] in a [[2006 World Cup|World Cup Finals]] match in [[Dortmund]], which led to violent clashes. The police detained over 300 people in Dortmund and German fans threw chairs, bottles and [[fireworks]] at the police. Of the 300 arrested, 120 were known hooligans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,2144,2056489,00.html |title=Hooligan Violence Rears Its Head for Germany-Poland Game |publisher=Dw-world.de |date= |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref> In October 2006, a task force was established to deal with violence and racism in German football stadiums.<ref>Theo Zwanziger (president of the DFB) and Werner Hackmann (president of Bundesliga) held a crisis meeting following violence at several German lower-division matches</ref> The worst incident took place at a [[Regionalliga (football)|Third division (North)]] match between the [[Hertha BSC|Hertha BSC Berlin B-team]] and [[Dynamo Dresden]], in which 23 policemen were injured.<ref>Dynamo Dresden fans tried to invade the pitch, and threw missiles (including gas cartridges and plastic seats) at police. The police responded with batons and [[pepper spray]]. At a [[2. Fußball-Bundesliga|Second Division]] match between [[FC Augsburg]] and [[TSV 1860 München|1860 Munich]], 21 people were arrested and police used pepper spray to disperse fans. In addition, 70 amateur and youth matches in [[Siegen-Wittgenstein]] were called off when referees refused to take to the pitch, fearing for their safety.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,2144,2220570,00.html |title=Soccer Heads Set Up Anti-Violence Task Force |publisher=Dw-world.de |date= |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref> In February 2007 in [[Saxony]], all German lower league matches, from the fifth division downward were cancelled after about 800 fans attacked 300 police officers (injuring 39 of them) after a match between [[1. FC Lokomotive Leipzig|Lokomotive Leipzig]] and [[FC Erzgebirge Aue|Erzgebirge Aue]] II.<ref>{{cite web|author=Dagmar Breitenbach (nda) |url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,2144,2347918,00.html |title=Germany Cancels Soccer Schedule in Saxony in Response to Riots |publisher=Dw-world.de |date=14 February 2007 |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref> There were minor disturbances after the Germany and England match during the 2010 FIFA World Cup. An English flag was burned down amongst a mob of German supporters in [[Duisburg]]-Hamborn in Germany.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bwk9NsJcPrw&feature=re%ADlated |title=Germany vs England Duisburg-Hamborn(Burning England Flag) |publisher=YouTube |date=28 June 2010 |accessdate=2013-09-01}}</ref>
===Greece=== [[File:Panathinaikos-paok 1989.jpg|thumb|Hooligans of "GATE 13" Panathinaiko's attacking supporters of "GATE 4" Paok and punched in field of Leoforos Alexandras stadium.]] The first incidents between Football fans in Greece were recorded in June 1930, after the match between [[Aris Thessaloniki]] and [[Panathinaikos F.C.]] at Thessaloniki. While Panathinaikos fans where arriving at the port of [[Piraeus]] from [[Thessaloniki]], Olympiakos fans, who had not forgotten the big loss of their team (8–2) by [[Panathinaikos F.C.]] rioted with the green fans. The word "hooliganism" was recorded at the early '60s where Greek students in the UK who had experienced the phenomenon of hooliganism there first taught the term to the journalists who were unable to explain why the fans were fighting each other and gave this situation a name. In 1962, after [[Panathinaikos F.C.]] and [[P.A.O.K. F.C.]] match incidents, newspapers wrote for the first time that hooligans (Χούλιγκανς) vandalized [[Apostolos Nikolaidis Stadium]]. It was on 19 November 1966 that a big flag, at the 13th gate of [[Apostolos Nikolaidis Stadium]] announced the arrival of a new group on the scene. [[Gate 13]] would be the first organized group that over the years became a part of the club by affecting club decisions and by following the club on all possible occasions. [[P.A.O.K. F.C.]] fans made Gate 4 in 1978 and [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]] fans create the Gate 7 in 1981. In 1982, between Aris FC – Paok FC match incidents, Aris Dimitriadis was stabbed and later died in Thessaloniki's hospital. On 26 October 1986, at the Alkazar stadium of Larissa Charalambos Blionas was killed by a flare pistol thrown by the Paok fans. One month later anastasios Zontos was stabbed to death in Omonoia square in the center of Athens before the match [[AEK Athens F.C.]] & [[P.A.O.K. F.C.]]. In January 1991, before the derby of Aek F.C. and Olympiakos F.C., George Panagiotou died in the incidents between hooligans outside Nea Filadelfia's stadium hit by flare pistol. On 15 May 2005, in [[Thessaloniki]] derby [[Iraklis Thessaloniki F.C.|Iraklis]]-[[Aris F.C. (Thessaloniki)|Aris F.C.]], Aris' hooligans called ''Ierolohites'' invaded the pitch when the score was 2–1 for Iraklis. A football player Tasos Katsambis was injured during the clashes. The match was halted and [[Aris F.C. (Thessaloniki)|Aris]] was punished with a 4-point deduction which led to their relegation to the [[Second Division (Greece)|Second Division]]. In April 2007, all sports stadiums were closed down in [[Greece]] for two weeks following the death of a fan in a pre-arranged fight between hooligans in [[Athens]] on 29 March. The fight involved 500 fans of rival [[Super League Greece]] clubs [[Panathinaikos F.C.|Panathinaikos]], which is based in Athens, and [[Olympiacos F.C.|Olympiacos]], which is based in nearby [[Piraeus]]. The [[Politics of Greece|Greek government]] immediately suspended all team sports in Greece and severed the ties between teams and their supporters' organizations.<ref name="Tribune001">{{Cite news| last = Kitsantonis | first = Niki | title = Soccer: Greece wrestles with fan violence| work=International Herald Tribune | date = 19 April 2007 | url = http://www.iht.com/articles/2007/04/19/sports/GREEKS.php | accessdate = 2007-11-24 }}</ref> A [[Third Division (Greece)|Third Division]] match between [[Panetolikos]] and [[Ilioupoli GS|Ilioupoli]] was stopped for thirty minutes when players and fans clashed following a Panetolikos disallowed goal. Two players and a coach were sent to the hospital.<ref name="Reuters001">{{Cite news| title = Soccer-Roundup-3-Greek police investigate lower league riots | publisher = Reuters| date = 16 April 2007| url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/UK_SOCCER_MORE/idUKL16150940220070416 | accessdate = 2007-11-24 }}</ref>
On 18 April, rival fans clashed with each other and riot police in [[Ioannina]] during and after a [[Greek football Cup|Greek Cup]] semi-final match between local rivals [[PAS Giannena]] and [[AEL 1964|Larissa]]. There was trouble during the game in which Larissa won 2–0. Fans set fire to [[Waste container|rubbish bins]] and smashed shop windows, while police tried to disperse them by firing tear gas.<ref name="Tribune001"/><ref name="novasports.gr" />
On 10 October 2009, a group of about 30 hooligans disrupted an "Under 17" match between local rivals PAOK and [[Aris Thessaloniki]]. Among the injured were a group of Aris Thessaloniki players and their coach, a veteran PAOK player and another official. On 7 October 2011, a group of Greek supporters firebombed the away section of a Euro 2012 qualifying match against Croatia in Athens. On 18 March 2012, during the match for the Super League Greek Championship in Athens Olympic Stadium between Panathinaikos and Olympiakos, home team Panathinaikos's fans who were inside the stadium attacked police forces with Molotov bombs, causing extended damages to the stadium, while police forces were unable to keep peace. [[File:Panathinaikos-olumpiakos-eksedra.jpg|thumb|Panathinaikos fans burn "spoils" inside stadium which were gained in battles against hooligans of Olympiakos in the past year.]] On 5 January 2014, in [[Aigaleo]], a suburb in [[Athens]], the local team [[Aigaleo FC]] was hosting [[AEK Athens]], a [[Third Division (Greece)|Third Division]] match. Before the match clashes broke up between [[AEK Athens|AEK]] and [[Aigaleo FC|Aigaleo]] fans. Indeed, the clashes resulted in the arrest of a security guard of the stadium who was accused of participating in the clashes among [[Aigaleo]] hooligans and also accused of committing attempted murder against an [[AEK Athens|AEK]] fan.
On 15 September 2014, in [[Nea Alikarnassos]], the team Herodotus<ref>[[:el:Π.Α.Σ.Α. Ηρόδοτος]]</ref> was hosting [[Ethnikos Piraeus]] , a [[Third Division (Greece)|Third Division]] match. On 75' minute of the game, a clash between the supporters of the two clubs forced the referee to stop the match. During the clash, a 45-year-old supporter of Ethnikos Piraeus suffered a severe head injury and died two weeks later.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.enikos.gr/sports/263130,Traymatismos_fila8loy_sto_Hrodotos-E8nik.html|title=Λιποθύμησε φίλαθλος στο Ηρόδοτος-Εθνικός|publisher=|accessdate=3 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.contra.gr/Soccer/Hellas/pethane-o-traymatias-filathlos-toy-ethnikou.3053057.html|title=Πέθανε ο τραυματίας φίλαθλος του Εθνικού|date=29 September 2014|work=Contra.gr|accessdate=3 May 2016}}</ref>
===Hungary=== [[Local derby|Local derbies]] between [[Budapest]] teams [[Ferencvárosi Torna Club]] (based in [[Ferencváros]]) and [[Újpest FC]] (based in [[Újpest]]) are frequently occasions for violence between supporters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hungarianfootball.com/2012/05/ujpest-vs-ferencvaros-a-background/|title=Újpest vs Ferencváros, A background |publisher=HungarianFootball.com|accessdate=24 September 2012}}</ref> Other clubs whose supporters are reportedly involved in hooliganism include [[Debreceni VSC]] ([[Debrecen]]), [[Diósgyőri VTK]] ([[Miskolc]]), [[Nyíregyháza Spartacus FC]] ([[Nyíregyháza]]), Zalaegerszegi TE ([[Zalaegerszeg]]), Haladás VSE ([[Szombathely]]) and Videoton FC ([[Székesfehérvár]])
===Italy=== The term ''[[wikt:ultrà|ultrà]]'' or ''[[wikt:ultras|ultras]]'' is used to describe hooligans in Italy.
In February 2001, [[A.S. Roma]] fans fought with police and [[Liverpool F.C.]] fans, and five English supporters were stabbed.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/1172748.stm |title=Fans recover after Rome stabbings |publisher=BBC News |date=16 February 2001 |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref>
After a weekend of violence in January 2007, the president of the [[Italian Football Federation]] (FIGC) threatened to halt all league football. An official of amateur club Sammartinese died when he was caught up in a fight between players and fans in [[Luzzi]], among numerous incidents of disorder in [[Florence]], [[Bergamo]] and elsewhere.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/europe/6314949.stm |title=Violence could halt Italian games |publisher=BBC News |date=30 January 2007 |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref> In February 2007 the Italian Football Federation (FIGC) suspended all football matches after Police Officer Filippo Raciti was killed at the match between [[Catania]] and [[Palermo]] when he was struck on his liver by a piece of lavatory of the stadium.<ref>{{cite web|last=Salopek |first=Paul |url=http://www.iht.com/articles/2007/02/04/sports/fans.php |title=The New York Times – Breaking News, World News & Multimedia |publisher=International Herald Tribune |date= |accessdate=2013-11-23}}</ref>
===Montenegro=== In a [[Euro 2016]] qualifying match in [[Podgorica]] on 27 March 2015, a few seconds in, a hooligan threw a flare at Russia goalkeeper [[Igor Akinfeev]] injuring him. The match was then temporarily suspended. Later fighting between the teams and more hooliganism rendered the game abandoned.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/32096292|title=Russia keeper Akinfeev hit by flare in abandoned Montenegro match|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=3 May 2016}}</ref>
===Netherlands=== The earliest recorded case of hooliganism in the Netherlands occurred when [[Rotterdam]] club [[Feyenoord]] and English club [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] met at the 1974 [[UEFA Cup]] Final, where Tottenham hooligans destroyed portions of the Feyenoord stadium tribunes. It was the first time the Netherlands encountered such destructive hooliganism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportgeschiedenis.nl/2007/01/12/feyenoord-en-de-voetbalrellen-van-1974.aspx |title=de alternatieve bron voor sportnieuws |publisher=Sportgeschiedenis.nl |date=26 April 1989 |accessdate=2013-09-01}}</ref> Other Dutch clubs associated with hooliganism include [[PSV Eindhoven]], [[AFC Ajax|Ajax]], [[FC Utrecht]], [[FC Groningen]], [[Twente Enschede]] and [[ADO Den Haag]].
The most violent rivalry is between Ajax and Feyenoord. A particularly serious incident was the so-called "[[Battle of Beverwijk]]" on 23 March 1997, in which several people were seriously injured and one killed.<ref>{{Cite news| title =The battle that undermines Ajax's search for beautiful game |url =http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/european_football/article1336946.ece | publisher =[[Times Online]]| date= 6 February 2007 | accessdate = 2007-05-26 | location=London | first=Rick | last=Broadbent}}</ref> The 2002–03 season was marked by similar incidents, and also by fighting between fans of Ajax and FC Utrecht.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.expatica.com/actual/article.asp?channel_id=1&story_id=54 |title=The rise of Dutch football hooliganism < Dutch news | Expatica The Netherlands |publisher=Expatica.com |date= |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref> [[File:PSV Hooligans.jpg|thumb|Mural on the wall near [[PSV Eindhoven|PSV]]'s [[Philips Stadion]]]]
Other serious incidents include: * 16 June 1990, English fans were arrested for brawling before a World Cup match against the Netherlands in Italy.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0CE0DA1639F934A25755C0A966958260 |title=English Soccer Fans Riot Before Match Against the Netherlands |publisher=New York Times |date=17 June 1990 |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref> * 26 April 1999, 80 hooligans were arrested for rioting after Feyenoord won the title after having played [[NAC Breda]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/WORLD/europe/9904/26/dutch.soccer.riot/ |title=One critically wounded during Rotterdam soccer riot |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date=26 April 1999 |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref> *19 February 2015, Feyenoord hooligans attacked Italian police with glass bottles and firecrackers in [[Piazza di Spagna]] before Europa League match [[A.S. Roma]]-[[Feyenoord]],28 Dutch fans were arrested.
===Poland=== {{further|Football hooliganism in Poland}}
One of the biggest riots occurred at a [[1994 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA – Group 2)|World Cup qualifying match]] between Poland and England on 29 May 1993 in [[Chorzów]].
Arranged football hooligan fights in Poland are known as ''[[wikt:ustawka|ustawki]]''; they became common in Poland since the late 90s. On 30 March 2003, [[Polish police]] arrested 120 people after rival football supporters fought during a match between [[Śląsk Wrocław]] and [[Arka Gdynia]].<ref name="BBC2901451">{{Cite news| title = Man killed in Polish football riot | publisher = BBC News | date = 30 March 2003 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/2901451.stm | accessdate = 2007-10-02 }}</ref> During the [[Wrocław football riot 2003|riot]], [[hooliganism|hooligans]] pelted police officers with stones and fought a running battle with knives and axes. One victim was seriously injured and later died in hospital.
During the [[UEFA Cup 1998-99|1998–99 UEFA Cup]], a knife was thrown at Italian footballer [[Dino Baggio]], from [[Parma F.C.]] by Polish supporters (allegedly [[Wisła Kraków]] fans), injuring his head.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.igol.pl/article,3402.html |title=W krainie latających noży |publisher=Igol.pl |date= |accessdate=2010-03-24 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080430181126/http://www.igol.pl/article,3402.html |archive-date=30 April 2008 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Supporters of [[Legia Warszawa]] also attracted negative attention after in Lithuania during the match against [[Vetra Vilnius]] on 10 July 2007.
The most notable hooligan incidents happened in [[Kraków]] where supporters of the [[Wisła Kraków]] and [[KS Cracovia]] teams have a rivalry that reportedly extended to killings of opposing fans.
Country-wide riots involving football fans were seen in [[Słupsk street riots 1998|1998 in Słupsk]] and [[Knurów riots 2015|2015 in Knurów]], both incidents sparked by a killing of a fan by the police.
===Republic Of Ireland=== Football Hooliganism was never an issue in Ireland up until the early 2000s and involved many pre match fights began to spawn in areas such as County Louth, Dublin and Derry. The behaviour of fans in these areas involved fights, racist chants and banners and many different pyrotechnic tools such as flares, smoke bombs and strobes. Often enough the away team and League of Ireland matches would be ganged up on by the home teams and attacked. ===Russia=== [[File:Hooligans of Spartak Moscow 1.jpg|thumb |Hooligans of [[FC Spartak Moscow|Spartak Moscow]]]]
Football hooliganism has become prevalent in Russia since the beginning of the 2000s, Hooligans are associated with teams such as [[FC Spartak Moscow]] (Gladiators, Shkola, Union), [[FC Lokomotiv Moscow]] (Red-Green's, Vikings, BHZ, Trains Team), [[PFC CSKA Moscow]] (RBW, Gallant Steeds, Yaroslavka, Einfach Jugend), [[FC Dynamo Moscow]] (Capitals, 9-ka), [[FC Torpedo Moscow]] (Tubes, TroubleMakers) – all from Moscow – and [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg]] (Music Hall, Coalition, Snakes Firm) from [[Saint Petersburg]]. Russian hooligans often show an underlying resentment towards Russia's perceived political rivals.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/2035137.stm |title=In pictures: Moscow football riot |publisher=BBC News |date=9 June 2002 |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/internationals/6152682.stm |title=BBC Sport: Croatia top after win in Israel |publisher=BBC News |date=15 November 2006 |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/low/football/internationals/6152682.stm |title=BBC Sport: Croatia top after win in Israel |publisher=BBC News |date=15 November 2006 |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/2034878.stm |title=Moscow riot prompts World Cup rethink |publisher=BBC News |date=10 June 2002 |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.people.com.cn/200206/10/eng20020610_97489.shtml |title=Soccer Riot in Russia Kills One |publisher=English.people.com.cn |date=10 June 2002 |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2001/WORLD/africa/05/09/soccer.chronology/ |title=CNN: Disasters in soccer stadiums – 10 May 2001 |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date=10 May 2001 |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref> At the [[UEFA Euro 2016]] tournament, 50 Russian fans were deported and the international team fined €150,000 following [[Violence at UEFA Euro 2016|co-ordinated violent attacks]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-36515575|title=Euro 2016: Who is to blame for the Marseille violence?|work=BBC News|date=14 June 2016|accessdate=14 June 2016}}</ref> [[File:Plastic chairs on the stadion broken by soccer hooligans. Bryansk, Russia, 2008.jpg|thumb|The aftermath of a football riot in [[Bryansk]], Russia: broken chairs and seats.]]
===Serbia=== The most prominent groups of hooligans are associated with [[Belgrade]] and [[Serbia]]'s two main clubs, [[Red Star Belgrade]] and [[FK Partizan|Partizan Belgrade]]. They are known as the ''[[Delije]]'' ("Heroes") and ''[[Grobari]]'' ("Gravediggers"), respectively. [[FK Rad]] is a less-successful Belgrade club, whose associated hooligans, known locally as "''United Force''", have notoriously been involved in many violent incidents.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://observer.guardian.co.uk/osm/story/0,,1123137,00.html |title=The Observer: Football, blood and war |publisher=Observer.guardian.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2010-03-24 | location=London}}</ref> On 2 December 2007, a plainclothes police officer was seriously injured when he was attacked during a [[Serbian Superliga]] match between [[Red Star Belgrade]] and [[FK Hajduk Kula|Hajduk Kula]].<ref>The officer was attacked with burning flares and broken seats and he had to fire warning shots in the air in self-defence. He was treated for burns, cuts and bruises in a nearby hospital. The following day, the [[Football Association of Serbia]] requested government help to help crack down on football hooliganism in the country.</ref><ref name="ReutersidUKL0320214820071203">{{Cite news| last = Milosavljevic| first = Zoran| title = Soccer-Serbian government to take tougher stance on hooligans| publisher = Reuters | date = 13 December 2007 | url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/worldFootballNews/idUKL0320214820071203 | accessdate = 2007-12-04 }}</ref> On 14 April 2008 a football fan was killed near [[Novi Sad]] after clashes between [[FK Partizan]]'s [[Grobari]] and fans of [[FK Vojvodina]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/worldFootballNews/idUKL1686240920080416 |title=Soccer-Serbian FA issues anti-hooliganism appeal |publisher=Uk.reuters.com |date=16 April 2008 |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref> That same week, after a Red Star Belgrade-Partizan cup match, three people were injured and a bus destroyed by hooligans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/info/vesti/index.php?yyyy=2008&mm=04&dd=17&nav_category=12&nav_id=294429 |title=Vesti – Nova divljanja huligana – Internet, Radio i TV stanica; najnovije vesti iz Srbije |publisher=B92 |date= |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref> [[File:Praha, Staré Město, Můstek, tag HCZ.JPG|thumb|Football firm [[graffiti]] in Prague.]] On 19 September 2008 a Serbian football hooligan was sentenced to ten years in jail for an attack against a police officer at a [[Red Star Belgrade]]–[[FK Hajduk Kula|Hajduk Kula]] game.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/eng/news/crimes.php?yyyy=2008&mm=09&dd=19&nav_id=53610|title=Red Star hooligan sentenced to 10 years|work=B92.net|accessdate=3 May 2016}}</ref> On 12 October 2010 Serbia's Euro 2012 Qualifying clash with Italy was abandoned after only 6 minutes after several Serbian fans threw flares and fireworks onto the pitch and caused severe trouble in and out of the ground.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://newsbeta.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/9086046.stm |title=BBC Sport – Football – Uefa begins investigation into Serbia fan violence |publisher=Newsbeta.bbc.co.uk |date=13 October 2010 |accessdate=2013-09-01}}</ref> Partizan Belgrade were disqualified from the UEFA Cup, after crowd trouble in Mostar, Bosnia & Herzegovina. Partizan fans threw flares and stones and fought with supporters of Zrinjski Mostar and police. Fourteen Partizan fans were convicted for the murder of [[Toulouse FC]] fan Brice Taton in Belgrade. They attacked him and other fans with baseball bats and flares while wearing surgical masks. The hooligans received up to 35 years in prison.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-12279960 | work=BBC News | title=Serbia football fans jailed for 2009 Brice Taton murder | date=25 January 2011}}</ref>
===Spain=== Football [[hooliganism]] in Spain arises from three main sources. The first is racism, as some [[black people|black]] players have been victims of [[list of ethnic slurs|ethnic slurs]]. [[Samuel Eto'o]], a former [[FC Barcelona]] player from [[Cameroon]], has denounced the problem.
The second source is the strong [[Major football rivalries|rivalry]] between [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]] and [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]]. After transferring from Barcelona to Real Madrid, [[Luís Figo]]'s appearance in Barcelona's [[Camp Nou|Nou Camp]] Stadium triggered a strong reaction. The crowd threw bottles, mobile phones and other things (including a pig's head). Although nobody was injured the match was followed by a large discussion on fan violence in the Spanish [[La Liga|Primera División]].
Hooliganism is also rooted in deep political divisions arising from the [[General Franco]] fascist regime days (some [[Real Madrid]], [[Atlético Madrid]], [[Espanyol]], [[Real Betis Balompie]] or [[Valencia CF]] ultras are linked to franquista groups), the communist ones, (such as [[Deportivo de La Coruña|Deportivo La Coruña]], [[Athletic Club Bilbao]], [[Sevilla FC]], [[Celta de Vigo]], [[Rayo Vallecano]]) and the independentist movements in [[Catalonia]] (like [[FC Barcelona]]), [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]] and the [[Basque Country (greater region)|Basque]] region. In Spain, organized hooligan groups are popularly called ''grupos ultra''. Three notorious ones are the [[Boixos Nois]], the Frente Atlético and the Ultras Sur, supporter groups of FC Barcelona, Atlético Madrid and Real Madrid respectively.
In 1991, [[Frederiq Roiquier]], a French supporter of [[Espanyol de Barcelona]] was killed by [[FC Barcelona]] hooligans which mistook him for an Espanyol hooligan.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://elpais.com/diario/1991/01/30/deportes/665190001_850215.html |title=Un 'ultra' azulgrana afirma que la muerte de un joven francés fue rigurosamente planeada | Edición impresa | EL PAÍS |publisher=Elpais.com |date=30 January 1991 |accessdate=2013-09-01}}</ref> In 1992 a 13-year-old child died in [[Espanyol]] stadium before a flare impact in his thorax.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/archivo/documento/MAM-65085 |title=MURIÓ UN NIÑO POR BENGALA EN ESPAÑA – Archivo – Archivo Digital de Noticias de Colombia y el Mundo desde 1.990 |publisher=eltiempo.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-01}}</ref> In 1998, Aitor Zabaleta, a supporter of [[Real Sociedad]] was killed by an [[Atlético Madrid]] hooligan<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.20minutos.es/noticia/247076/l/ |title=El Tribunal Supremo confirma la pena por desórdenes contra Ricardo Guerra y otros miembros del grupo ultra Bastión |trans-title=The Supreme Court confirmed the sentence for disorderly conduct against Ricardo Guerra and other group members ultra Bastión |language=Spanish |publisher=20 Minutos |date=13 June 2007 |accessdate=2010-09-04}}</ref> who was linked to a neo-Nazi group (Bastión), just before a match between these two teams. In 2003, a supporter of [[Deportivo de La Coruña|Deportivo La Coruña]] was killed in riots by Deportivo hooligans, when he tried to protect a supporter of the opposing team, [[SD Compostela]]. Since then, authorities have made attempts to bring hooliganism more under control. In 2007, there were acts of hooliganism before a match between Atlético Madrid and Real Madrid, with several cars being destroyed and policemen injured by flares and bottles which were thrown at them.<ref>{{Cite news| title =Vandal incidents in Madrid|url =http://www.elcomerciodigital.com/prensa/20070225/deportes/vandalismo-frente-atletico_20070225.html | publisher =[[El Correo Digital]]| date= 24 February 2007| accessdate = 2007-02-24}}</ref>
Many black foreign players have been racially abused, such as at a 2004 friendly match between Spain and England, in which black England players such as [[Shaun Wright-Phillips]] and [[Ashley Cole]] endured [[monkey chants]] from Spain supporters.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/monkey-chants-force-clampdown-on-spains-racist-football-fans-525020.html |title='Monkey chants' force clampdown on Spain's racist football fans – Europe, World |publisher=The Independent |date=29 January 2006 |accessdate=2010-03-24 | location=London | first=Graham | last=Keeley}}</ref> There also have been local disputes between rival teams, for example between [[Cádiz Club de Fútbol]] and [[Xerez CD]], [[Real Betis Balompie]] and [[Sevilla FC]] or [[Deportivo de La Coruña]] and [[Celta de Vigo]].
Hooligan violence in Spain decreased since the late '90s due to an alcohol ban in sporting events as well as hooligan laws which attempt fines up to 600,000 euros and bans of two years without access to stadiums.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csd.gob.es/csd/informacion/legislacion-basica/ley-del-deporte |title=Ley del Deporte – Portal del Consejo Superior de Deportes |language=es |publisher=Csd.gob.es |date=1 January 2000 |accessdate=2013-09-01}}</ref>
Since 2003 [[FC Barcelona]] hooligans, the [[Boixos Nois]] are not allowed to enter in [[Camp Nou]]. The hardcore of Barcelona hooligans subgroups were involved in police operations against organized crime.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elperiodico.com/es/noticias/sociedad/20100919/casuals-una-mafia-catalana/486250.shtml |title=Casuals, una mafia catalana – Sociedad – El Periódico |publisher=Elperiodico.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-01}}</ref> In 2008, after a hooligan incident versus [[Espanyol]], [[FC Barcelona]] very publicly took a stand on violence, saying it hoped to stamp out violence for good.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fcbarcelona.cat/web/english/noticies/club/temporada08-09/09/n080928105461.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120801194615/http://www.fcbarcelona.cat/web/english/noticies/club/temporada08-09/09/n080928105461.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=1 August 2012 |title=FCBarcelona.cat |publisher=FCBarcelona.cat |date=28 September 2008 |accessdate=2010-03-24 }}</ref> In 2007 [[Atlético Madrid]] hooligans clashed with Aberdeen FC hooligans prior to a [[UEFA Cup]] match.In 2009 and 2010 [[Atlético Madrid]] hooligans also clashed with [[FC Porto]] and [[Sporting Clube de Portugal]] in Portugal during [[UEFA Cup]] games. In 2012 a [[Rayo Vallecano]] Hooligan was arrested during riots in 14-November general strike and accused of terrorism.
In 2014, debate about eradicating Spanish hooligans arose after Frente Atlético members murdered a Riazor Blues member, [[Deportivo La Coruña]] radicals; and after members of the [[Boixos Nois]] stabbed two [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|PSG]] supporters in Barcelona.
In 2016, Football-related violence came once again to the public debate after a Fight between [[Sevilla FC]] and [[Juventus FC]] Supporters that occurred the day before their [[UEFA Champions League]] group stage match. 2 Juventus supporters were stabbed (one of them was seriously injured but survived after being hospitalized) and a Sevilla supporter was hospitalized with head wounds caused by a glass bottle.
===Sweden=== Hooliganism began in Sweden at the turn of the 20th century as fans of [[AIK Fotboll|AIK]], [[Hammarby IF|Hammarby]] and [[Djurgårdens IF Fotboll|Djurgården]] have been reported fighting after derbies in [[Stockholm]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2007}} Modern hooliganism began in 1970 when fans of [[IFK Göteborg]] invaded the pitch, destroyed the goalposts and fought the police at the end of a match that relegated Göteborg from the [[Allsvenskan]], although Hooliganism in Sweden became a growing problem in the 1980s, but [[pitch invasion]]s and violence at football grounds decreased in the late 1990s; when hooligan firms started pre-arranging their fights away from the grounds and the regular supporters. Seven clubs that have large organised hooligans firms are [[AIK Fotboll|AIK]] (Firman Boys), [[IFK Göteborg]] (Wisemen) [[Djurgårdens IF Fotboll|Djurgårdens IF]] (DFG) [[Hammarby IF]] (KGB) [[Malmö FF]] (True Rockers) [[GAIS]] (Gärningsmännen) and [[Helsingborgs IF]] (Frontline). But several other football, bandy and ice hockey clubs have active hooligan followings.<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk">{{Cite news| title =First Swedish football death |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/not_in_website/syndication/monitoring/media_reports/2169007.stm | publisher =BBC News| date= 2 August 2002 | accessdate = 2007-04-28}}</ref> In November 2002, 12 members of the Wisemen stood trial for inflicting life-threatening injuries on a [[Hammarby IF|Hammarby]] fan in 2001.<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk"/>
In August 2002, [[Tony Deogan]], a member of the Wisemen, was killed after a pre-arranged fight against Firman Boys.<ref name="news.bbc.co.uk"/> A second fatality occurred in March 2014, when a 43-year-old [[Djurgårdens IF Fotboll|Djurgården]] supporter was killed in [[Helsingborg]] in an assault on his way to Djurgården's opening match in the [[2014 Allsvenskan]] against [[Helsingborgs IF|Helsingborg]]. After the man's death became known, Djurgården supporters invaded the pitch after 42 minutes of play, prompting officials to abandon the match.<ref name="Djurgården fan killed">{{cite web |url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/sportbladet/fotboll/sverige/allsvenskan/djurgarden/article18634468.ab |title=Djurgårdssupporter misshandlad till döds |work=[[Aftonbladet]] |language=Swedish |last1=Svensson |last2=Wagner |first1=Olof |first2=Michael |date=30 March 2014 |accessdate=2014-03-30}}</ref><ref name="Tragedy in Helsingborg">{{cite web | url=https://svenskfotboll.se/allsvenskan/arkiv/allsvenskan/tt/2014/03/helsingborg-djurgarden-avbruten/ | title=Djurgårdssupporter död efter bråk | publisher=The Swedish Football Association | work=svenskfotboll.se | date=30 March 2014 | accessdate=2 April 2014 | language=Swedish}}</ref>
===Switzerland=== In Switzerland, hooligan incidents are rare due to the fact that the stadiums are small and teams are little.
One incident, dubbed the [[2006 Basel Hooligan Incident]], 13 May 2006, occurred on the last day of the 2005–06 season, when [[FC Zürich]] defeated [[FC Basel]] at [[St. Jakob Park]] to win the Swiss championship with a last-minute goal. After the final whistle, angry Basel hooligans stormed the field and attacked Zürich players. The Zürich team were forced to celebrate in the upper deck of the stands while the fighting continued. There was similar fighting in the streets that night.<ref name="nzz.ch">{{cite web|url=http://www.nzz.ch/2006/11/23/eng/article7274780.html |accessdate=6 December 2006 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref name="nzz.ch"/>
===Turkey===
According to the ''[[Turkish Daily News]]'', hooligan groups are well organised, have their own "leaders", and often consist of organised [[street fighting|street fighters]]. These groups have a "racon" (code of conduct), which states that the intention must be to [[injury|injure]] rather than [[murder|kill]] and that a stab must be made below the waist.<ref name="fatalmistakes">{{Cite news| title = Chain of Fatal Mistakes | url = http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/h.php?news=chain-of-fatal-mistakes-2000-04-16 | publisher = [[Turkish Daily News]]| date = 16 April 2000| accessdate = 2006-10-06}}</ref> Other hooligans have fired firearms into the air to celebrate their team's victory, which has been known to accidentally kill innocent people watching the celebrations on their balconies.<ref name="passionofturks">{{Cite news| title = Passion of Turkish fans| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/704374.stm| publisher = BBC News| date = 6 April 2000| accessdate = 2006-10-06}}</ref><ref name="givingperspective">{{Cite news| title = Giving perspective to football violence| url = http://www.soccernet.com/euro2000/columns/20000521featmike.html| publisher = [[Soccernet]]| date = 20 May 2000| accessdate = 2006-10-06}}</ref>
Trouble has arisen during matches between Istanbul rivals Galatasaray and Fenerbahçe.<ref name="passionofturks" /> However, the [[Turkish Football Federation]] has tightened security to try and contain the hooliganism. During the 2005 [[Turkish Football Cup|Turkish cup final]] between [[Galatasaray S.K. (football team)|Galatasaray]] and [[Fenerbahçe S.K.|Fenerbahçe]], 8,000 police, [[Football steward|stewards]] and officials were employed to prevent violence.<ref name="istanbulready">{{Cite news| title = Istanbul ready to host final| url = http://www.newagebd.com/2005/may/15/spt.html| publisher = New Age Sports| location = Bangladesh| date = 15 May 2005| accessdate = 2006-10-06| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20061028021547/http://www.newagebd.com/2005/may/15/spt.html| archivedate = 28 October 2006| df = dmy-all}}</ref> In 2006, the Turkish Football Federation introduced new measures to combat the threat of hooliganism and have made new regulations that allow the Professional Football Disciplinary Board to fine clubs up to YTL 250,000 for their fans behavior. Repeat offenders could be fined up to YTL 500,000.<ref name="TFFnewmeasures">{{Cite news| title = Turkish Football Federation Introduces New Series of Penalties| url = http://www.zaman.com/?bl=sports&alt=&hn=35506| publisher = [[Zaman (newspaper)|Zaman]], Turkish newspaper| date = 9 August 2006| accessdate = 2006-10-06| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110605050813/http://www.zaman.com/?bl=sports&alt=&hn=35506| archivedate = 5 June 2011| df = dmy-all}}</ref> Despite reports from the Turkish Football Federation, the Turkish police believe that football hooliganism is not a major threat and are "isolated incidents".<ref name="wcarchives">{{Cite news| title = The Soccerphile World Cup 2002 Archives | url = http://www.soccerphile.com/soccerphile/archives/wc2002/ne/hrgps.html| publisher = Soccerphile.com, World Cup Soccer and Global Football Information Website| date = 20 May 2002| accessdate = 2006-10-06}}</ref>
Before Galatasaray's [[UEFA Cup 1999-00#Semi-finals|semi-final UEFA Cup match]] with [[Leeds United A.F.C.|Leeds United]] in 2000, two Leeds fans, Christopher Loftus and Kevin Speight, were [[2000 UEFA Cup semi-final violence|stabbed to death]] in [[Istanbul]] following street fights between Turkish and British hooligans.<ref name="fatalmistakes"/> UEFA allowed the game to proceed and Galatasaray won 2–0. Leeds complained because home fans jeered while a message of condolence was read for the victims.<ref name="silenttribute">{{Cite news| title = Silent tribute to Leeds fans| url = http://newswww.bbc.net.uk/1/low/uk/706936.stm| publisher = BBC News| date = 9 April 2000| accessdate = 2006-10-06}}</ref> Galatasaray's players refused to wear black arm bands. The Leeds chairman at the time, [[Peter Ridsdale]], accused Galatasaray of "showing a lack of respect".<ref name="fourcharged">{{Cite news| title = Four charged with murder | url = http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/soccer/world/news/2000/04/10/leeds_anger_ap/| publisher = [[CNN Sports Illustrated]]| date = 10 April 2000 | accessdate = 2006-10-06}}</ref> He also revealed that his teams' players had received death threats before the match.<ref name="acceptturks">{{Cite news| title = Football: Uefa hints Leeds must accept Turks| url = http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_20000413/ai_n14299873| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20061023223639/http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_20000413/ai_n14299873| dead-url = yes| archive-date = 23 October 2006| work=[[The Independent]]| date = 13 April 2000| accessdate = 2006-10-06}}</ref>
Ali Ümit Demir was arrested and sentenced to 15 years imprisonment for the stabbing, but the sentence was reduced to 5 years on the basis of heavy provocation, while five others were given lesser sentences of under four months.<ref name="wcarchives"/> The families of those accused of attacking with knives are reported to have defended their actions and approved of their children punishing the "rude British people".<ref name="fatalmistakes" /> Galatasaray fans were banned from traveling to the return match to try and avoid further clashes between fans, although there were reports of attacks by Leeds fans on Turkish television crews and the police.<ref name="wildscenes">{{Cite news| title = Wild scenes greet Turkey's heroes| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/721664.stm| publisher = BBC News| date = 21 April 2000| accessdate = 2006-10-06}}</ref> However the Assistant Chief Constable in charge of policing the game believed that the number of arrests was "no worse than a normal high category game".<ref name="wildscenes" /> [[Hakan Şükür]] was hit with projectiles from Leeds United supporters and the Galatasaray team bus was stoned after driving through an underpass. The game saw [[Emre Belözoğlu]] and [[Harry Kewell]] sent off and Galatasaray sealed their way to the final with a 2–2 score.
[[2000 UEFA Cup Final riots|Violence]] also occurred between [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] fans (mainly from [[The Herd (hooligan firm)|The Herd]]) and Galatasaray fans before the [[UEFA Cup 1999-00#Final|2000 UEFA Cup final]] in Copenhagen<ref name="arsenalfear">{{Cite news| title = Arsenal fans fear more violence| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/752001.stm| publisher = BBC News| date = 17 May 2000| accessdate = 2006-10-06}}</ref> in which a Galatasaray fan, an Arsenal fan and a Dane were said to have been stabbed.<ref name="threemorestabbed">{{Cite news| title = Three more stabbed in Copenhagen| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/752001.stm| publisher = BBC News| date = 18 May 2000| accessdate = 2006-10-06}}</ref> Galatasaray later won the match after a penalty shoot-out.
On 24 May 2001, 50 people were injured when fighting broke out at a match between French club PSG and Galatasaray at the Parc des Princes stadium.[16][17]PSG were initially given a record $571,000 fine, but it was reduced on appeal to $114,000. Galatasaray was initially fined $114,000 by UEFA, but it too was eventually reduced to $28,500.[18] In May 2001, six PSG fans from the Supporters Club, were arrested and charged with assault, carrying weapons, throwing items on the pitch and racism. The six were alleged to have deliberately entered a part of the Parc des Princes stadium where French fans of Turkish origin were standing, in order to attack them. The six were banned from all football stadiums for the duration of their trial.
On 3 June 2011, after the Belgium vs. Turkey match, several riots occurred in the city center of Ghent after a 1–1 draw. 30 people were injured. Hooliganism in Turkey is also a problem in [[Ankara]], [[İzmir]], [[Eskişehir]], [[Bursa]], [[Samsun]] and [[Adana]] {{Citation needed|reason=This claim needs a reliable source; There is no known hooliganism issue in Adana, other than small events that happens everywhere in Turkey.|date=February 2012}}. During the 2003–2004 season, a [[Bank Asya First League|Second League Category A]], match between [[Karşıyaka S.K.|Karşıyaka]] and [[Göztepe A.Ş.|Göztepe]] on 8 February 2004, involved rival Karşıyaka and Göztepe supporters clashing and the match was subsequently stopped for 33 minutes. This was due to Karşıyaka leading 5–2 after coming back from a 2–0 deficit. After the match, Göztepe fans clashed with the police, seven police officers were wounded and fifteen Göztepe fans were arrested.<ref name="clash between fans">{{Cite news| title = Meydan savaşı| url = http://arsiv.sabah.com.tr/2004/02/09/spo112.html| publisher = [[Sabah]]| date = 9 February 2004| accessdate = 2008-07-19}}</ref>
Bursaspor fans clashed with policemen at a match against Samsunspor match in the [[Süper Lig]] in [[Adapazarı]] at the end of the 2003–04 season. The match was played in Adapazarı due to events at a previous match between Bursaspor and Çaykur Rizespor. Bursaspor were playing to avoid relegation. Bursaspor won 1–0 the but were relegated to [[Bank Asya First League|Category A]] after rivals won. After the match, Bursaspor fans ripped out and threw seats at the [[Sakarya Atatürk Stadium]]<ref name="clash after relegation">{{Cite news| title = Ve çirkinlik bitti| url = http://webarsiv.hurriyet.com.tr/2004/05/16/459911.asp| publisher = [[Hürriyet]]| date = 16 May 2004| accessdate = 2008-07-19}}</ref> They also fought with craftsmen of [[Gölcük, Kocaeli|Gölcük]] during their journey to Adapazarı.<ref name="Bursaspor fans fought with Gölcük's craftsmen">{{Cite news| title = Fanatikler Gölcük'ü birbirine kattı| url = http://www.aksam.com.tr/arsiv/aksam/2004/05/16/spor/spor13.html| publisher = [[Akşam]]| date = 16 May 2004| accessdate = 2008-07-19|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20040930161656/http://www.aksam.com.tr/arsiv/aksam/2004/05/16/spor/spor13.html |archivedate = 30 September 2004|deadurl=yes}}</ref> The Bursaspor-Diyarbakırspor game in March 2010 was suspended in the 17th minute after Diyarbakırspor supporters threw objects on the field. One object struck and knocked down an assistant referee.
On 7 May 2011, Bursaspor supporters clashed with the police ahead of the team's match with rival Beşiktaş. 25 police officers and 9 fans were injured in the violence.<ref name="bursa">{{Cite news| title = Police detain more than 100 after Bursaspor violence| url = https://sports.yahoo.com/soccer/news?slug=reu-turkeyviolence| publisher = [[Yahoo Sports]]| date = 8 May 2011| accessdate = 2011-05-29}}</ref> A Trabzonspor fan pointed a gun to the bus which carried the players of Fenerbahçe. During the Fenerbahçe-Galatasaray game at the end of 2011–2012 season Fenerbahçe fans clashed with the police the damage costed about 2 million dollars. Buses were stoned, Police cars set on fire and trees were set on fire by Fenerbahçe fans.This was described as a ''warzone''.
The 1967 Kayseri Atatürk Stadium Disaster was the worst hooliganism event that has ever happened in Turkey. It resulted in 40 deaths and some 600 were injured. The violence started following provocation of the Kayserispor fans in the half time, whose team went to leading by a goal scored in the first half.Supporters of the two teams threw rocks to each other.Some of the hooligans were also armed with bats and knives.The fleeing crowd caused a stampede in front of the stand exits.The events in the stadium were followed by vandalism in Kayseri and many-days lasting riots in Sivas. Hooliganism is also an issue in other sports like Basketball and Volleyball in Turkey.
On 13 May 2013, a Fenerbahce fan was stabbed to death after the Istanbul derby. The Fenerbahce fan was on his way back home after the match between Fenerbahçe and Galatasaray, when he was attacked by a group of Galatasaray fans at a bus stop, and died in hospital later.<ref>{{cite news|work=goal.com|url=http://www.goal.com/en-au/news/4016/main/2013/05/13/3975527/fenerbahce-fan-stabbed-to-death-after-istanbul-derby?source=breakingnews&ICID=HP_HL_6|title=Fenerbahce fan stabbed to death after Istanbul derby|first=Stefan|last=Coerts|date=13 May 2013}}</ref>
In 2015, confectioners [[Ülker]]–previously "one of Turkish football's biggest sponsors"–ceased their support, reportedly due to "low crowds, violence and poor atmosphere at matches".<ref>{{cite news|title=Turkish game ready to collapse as sponsors pull out|date=5 March 2015|work=wsc.co.uk|publisher=When Saturday Comes|accessdate=5 March 2015|url=http://www.wsc.co.uk/wsc-daily/1193-march-2015/12215-turkish-game-ready-to-collapse-as-sponsors-pull-out}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== {{Main|Football hooliganism in the United Kingdom}}
There are records of football hooliganism in the UK from the 1880s, and from no later than the 1960s the UK had a worldwide reputation for it – the phenomenon was often dubbed the ''English Disease''.<ref name="LiverpoolUni">{{cite web | url=http://www.liv.ac.uk/footballindustry/hooligan.html | title=FIG FACT-SHEET FOUR: HOOLIGANISM | accessdate=20 March 2011 | publisher=Football Industry Group, University of Liverpool}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | title='Football Hooliganism: Policing the War on the English Disease' | author=Stott, Clifford | year=2007 | publisher=Pennant Books | isbn=978-1-906015-05-3 | author2=Pearson, Geoff}}</ref><ref name="EnglishDiseaseBBC">{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/6532989.stm | title=The return of the English disease? | accessdate=20 March 2011 | date=6 April 2007 | publisher=BBC | first=Mario | last=Cacciottolo}}</ref><ref name="IndyEnglishDisease">{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/leading-articles/another-sorry-outbreak-of-the-english-disease-730590.html | title=Another sorry outbreak of the English disease | accessdate=20 March 2011 | date=17 June 2004 | publisher=The Independent on Sunday | location=London}}</ref>
From the 1970s, many organised hooligan firms sprang up, with most [[Football League]] clubs having at least one known organised hooligan element. Hooliganism was often as its worst when local rivals played each other. Supporters of teams including [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]], [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]], [[Tottenham Hotspur]], [[Portsmouth F.C|Portsmouth]], [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], [[Leicester City]] and [[Bristol City]] were among those most frequently linked to hooliganism.
Racism became a major factor in hooliganism around the same time, as black players became a regular feature in English league teams from the 1970s. Black players were frequently targeted with monkey chants, and had bananas thrown at them. Members of far-right groups including the [[National Front (UK)|National Front]] also sprayed racist slogans and distributed racist literature at matches.
[[Sectarian]] violence has long been a regular factor of crowd violence, as well as offensive chanting, at matches in [[Scotland]] between [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] and [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]].
As a result of the [[Heysel Stadium disaster]] at [[Brussels]], [[Belgium]], in [[1985 European Cup Final|1985]], where Liverpool FC fans rioting led to the death of 39 [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] fans, English clubs were banned from all European competitions until 1990, with Liverpool (the English team present) banned for an additional year.<ref name="hillsboroughjustice">{{Cite news| title = Michael Moore's Bowling For Columbine and the Hillsborough Justice Campaign | url = http://www.contrast.org/hillsborough/bowling.shtm | publisher = Hillsborough Justice Campaign | accessdate = 2006-10-07}}</ref> According to Manchester United hooligan Colin Blaney in his autobiography 'The Undesirables', many of the football hooligan gangs in the UK used hooliganism as a cover for acquisitive forms of crime, specifically theft and burglary.<ref>{{cite book |first=Colin |last=Blaney |title=Undesirables |year=2014 |publisher=John Blake |isbn=978-1782198970 |pages=1–10 }}</ref> This has also been confirmed in numerous other articles on the subject.<ref>{{cite news |first=Nick |last=Chester |title=Getting Life Lessons From Manchester's Jet-Setting Career Thieves |publisher=Vice Media |date=31 January 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=J. |last=Sugden |title=Inside the Grafters' Game: An Ethnographic Examination of Football's Underground Economy |publisher=Journal of Sport and Social Issues |date=January 2007 }}</ref> In the 1980s and well into the 1990s the UK government led a major crackdown on football-related violence. While football hooliganism has been a growing concern in some other European countries in recent years, British football fans now tend to have a better reputation abroad. Although reports of British football hooliganism still surface, the instances now tend to occur at pre-arranged locations including pubs rather than at the matches themselves.
English clubs who have made the headlines for the worst and most frequent cases of hooliganism include Birmingham City (whose multi racial hooligan element gained the nickname "Zulus" from fans of rival teams in the 1970s when football hooligans were almost always white British), Chelsea (whose then chairman [[Ken Bates]] installed an electric fence at the club's stadium in the mid 1980s to combat hooligans, but was refused permission to switch it on during matches), Leeds United (who were banned from European competitions following a riot after the 1975 European Cup final against Bayern München), Liverpool (14 of whose fans were convicted after a riot at the 1985 European Cup final resulted in the deaths of 39 spectators at Heysel Stadium in [[Belgium]] when a stadium wall collapsed, leading to English clubs being banned from European competitions for 5 years), Manchester United (who were booted out of the European Cup Winner's Cup in 1977 after their fans rioted at a game in France, although they were reinstated to the competition on appeal), Millwall (whose most notorious hooliganism incident was in 1985 when their fans rioted in an FA Cup tie at [[Luton]]), Tottenham Hotspur who gained notoriety for the 1974 UEFA Cup Final disturbances and again in Rotterdam in 1983 (who had a section of fans banned from all football grounds in England in 2008 for their racial and homophobic abuse of former player [[Sol Campbell]]) and Wolves (who had dozens of fans convicted of incidents in the late 1980s involving the [[Subway Army]] hooligan firm at matches against teams including Cardiff City and Scarborough when they were in the Fourth Division).
=== Ukraine === Football [[hooliganism]] movement in [[Ukraine]] started in the 1980s. The first big fight (more than 800 people) involving football hooligans was registered in September 1987 between [[Dynamo Kyiv]] and [[FC Spartak Moscow|Spartak Moscow]] fans in the center of [[Kiev]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rusplt.ru/society/okolofutbol-evromaydan-7827.html|title=Родом из советского околофутбола|publisher=|accessdate=3 May 2016}}</ref> The 1990s passed in relative silence, as there were no big fights between hooligans. The origin of the football hooligan movement in Ukraine started in the mid-90s. On September 5, 1998 an important game between [[Ukraine national football team|Ukraine]] and [[Russia national football team|Russia]]'s national football teams was played. Ukrainian hooligans began to unite in "National crews" to resist Russian fans. However, the mass union did not take place due to police intervention and were mainly composed of Ukrainian fans from [[Kiev]] and [[Dnipropetrovsk]]. In March 2001, several crews united and attacked 80 [[Belarusians|Belarusian]] fans after match between [[Ukraine national football team|Ukraine]] and [[Belarus national football team|Belarus national football]] teams. At that exact time hooligans and ultras were separated, due to changes of views on supporting movement. One part decided to dedicate all time at the tribune to create a choreo in Italian style, and the others decided to remain faithful to English style with fighting and the same wear style.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dynamo.kiev.ua/blog/91566-istoriya-i-natsionalnyie-osobennosti-fanatskogo-dvizheniya-ukrainyi-i-rossii|title=История и национальные особенности фанатского движения Украины и России|author=dynamo.kiev.ua|work=Новини Динамо К|accessdate=18 May 2013}}</ref> 15 April 2002 about 50 right Dynamo fans attacked [[Jewish]] quarter in [[Kiev]]. First, they stoned small shop and after that throw stoned in synagogue and beat up the head of synagogue and other believers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rus.delfi.ee/archive/v-kieve-skinhedy-razgromili-sinagogu?id=3452154|title=В Киеве скинхеды разгромили синагогу|author=rus.delfi.ee|work=rus.delfi.ee|accessdate=15 April 2002}}</ref>
Since 2005 clashes between hooligans occurred mostly outside the city because of the excessive attention of police. During the [[Euro 2012]] several leaders of football hooligans came under government pressure.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/competitions/euro-2012/9316682/Dont-judge-a-nation-like-Ukraine-by-its-hooligans.html|title=Don’t judge a nation like Ukraine by its hooligans|date=8 June 2012|work=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=3 May 2016}}</ref> During the [[2014 Ukrainian revolution|Ukrainian revolution 2014]] was announced about unification of all fans and imposed a ban on any provocation as burning attributes, fighting, offensive songs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://24tv.ua/ukrayina/obyednannya_ukrayini_uzhe_prodemonstruvali_ultras_i_futbolni_fani__poroshenko/n402531|title=Об'єднання України уже продемонстрували ультрас і футбольні фани, — Порошенко|author=24tv.ua|work=Телеканал новин 24|accessdate=3 May 2016}}</ref> During the [[war in eastern Ukraine]] many hooligans and ultras went to the defense of the state.
Because of the ban internal conflicts and successes in the international stage Ukrainian hooligans pay attention to foreign fans. After the match between [[FC Dnipro]] and [[AS Saint-Étienne|Saint Etienne]] in [[Kiev]] several French fans were hospitalized with the stabbing. August 20, 2015 there was a big fight in [[Hydropark (Kiev Metro)|Hydropark]] between [[Legia Warsaw|Legia]] and [[Dynamo Kyiv|Dynamo]]&[[Zorya Luhansk|Zorya]] hools.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ua.korrespondent.net/kyiv/3553356-u-kyievi-pobylysia-fanaty-dynamo-i-lehii|title=У Києві побилися фанати Динамо і Легії|publisher=|accessdate=3 May 2016}}</ref> The biggest clash since unification occurred in Kiev, 6 December 2016 between [[Dynamo Kiev|Dynamo]] and [[Besiktas]] hooligans.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ultras-tifo.net/photo-news/4651-cl-dynamo-kyiv-besiktas-06-12-2016.html|title=CL: DYNAMO KYIV - BESIKTAS 06.12.2016|author=ultras-tifo.net|work=Ultras' news cite|accessdate=7 December 2016}}</ref> For Turks it was very important match, because win of [[Turkey]] team mean's qualification to the European top stage. Few days before to Kiev came about 7,000 fans from [[Istanbul]]. Two days before match on the streets in different parts of Ukrainian capital witnessed the outbreak of numerous conflicts.
Typically the biggest confrontation involving Ukrainian hooligans occurring in domestic competitions. The most famous confrontation: [[Ukrainian derby|Klasychne derby]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.esquire.co.uk/culture/sport/7051/ukraine-ultras/|title=On The Terraces At Football's Most Dangerous Derby|author=Marc Bennetts|date=20 September 2014|work=Esquire|accessdate=3 May 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160109103218/http://www.esquire.co.uk/culture/sport/7051/ukraine-ultras/|archive-date=9 January 2016|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[w:uk:Суперництво футбольних клубів «Дніпро» та «Металіст»|South derby]] and South-West derby between [[FC Karpaty Lviv]] and [[Shakhtar Donetsk]]. There are local derbys as: [[Donetsk derby]] or [[Kyiv derby]].
==South America==
===Argentina=== {{further information|Barra brava}}
====1920s==== The first murder related with Argentine football occurred on 21 September 1922 in [[Rosario]], during the second half of a match between [[Tiro Federal|Tiro Federal Argentino]] (in its stadium) and [[Newell's Old Boys]] for the Copa Estímulo of the local first division, in a discussion between two fans. Enrique Battcock, a railroad worker and supporter of the home club (also former footballer and former member of the club's directing) was interpellated for Francisco Campá (Newell's Old Boys' supporter and member of the club's directing) for his behaviour, which carried a discussion that ended when Battcock hit in the face to Cambá, who retired from the stadium, returned after a little while, extracted a gun and shot him, causing Battcock's death.<ref>[http://salvemosalfutbol.org/lista-de-victimas-de-incidentes-de-violencia-en-el-futbol/ Victims list] Salvemos al Fútbol</ref>
On 2 November 1924 in [[Montevideo]] ([[Uruguay]]), occurred another murder where an Argentina fan was involved. After the final match of the [[1924 South American Championship|South American Championship]] of this year between Uruguay and Argentina (that Uruguay won), in the Colón Hotel (where the [[Argentine national football team]] was staying) broke out a fight among Uruguay supporters and Argentine fans and footballers, where José Lázaro Rodríguez (a recognized Argentine supporter of Boca Juniors and the national team) shot to Pedro Demby, an Uruguayan fan that died consequently.<ref>[http://pelotaafuera.blogspot.com/2009/11/85-anos-de-la-muerte-de-pedro-demby.html To 85 years of the death of Pedro Demby] Pelota Afuera</ref>
====1930s==== On 14 May 1939 at the stadium of [[Club Atlético Lanús|Lanús]] (in the city of [[Lanús]], in the [[Greater Buenos Aires]]), in a match of the minor divisions of the local team and Boca Juniors (previous to the match of the main teams of both clubs), after a foul committed by a player of Lanús, both teams began to fight. Seeing this, Boca Juniors fans wanted to tear down the fence and invade the pitch, prompting the police to fire shots to disperse them. But a police officer named Luis Estrella shot into the stands, killing two spectators: Luis López and Oscar Munitoli (a 9-year old).<ref>[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=920643 An undesirable list who grow...] La Nación</ref>
====1940s==== But this violence was not only among fans, footballers or the police, but also against the referees. On 27 October 1946, during a match between Newell's Old Boys and [[San Lorenzo de Almagro]] at Newell's Old Boys stadium (in the city of [[Rosario]]), local fans tried to strangle the referee Osvaldo Cossio. The match was tied on two goals when Cossio annulled a goal of the premises, and the third goal of San Lorenzo de Almagro in the next play worsened the situation. 89 minutes into the game, several Newell's Old Boys fans entered the pitch, hit the umpire and tried to hang him with his own belt.<ref>[http://www.lacapital.com.ar/contenidos/2010/03/17/noticia_0049.html The shortest match of the history] La Capital</ref>
====1950s==== Although in [[Football in Argentina|Argentine football]] violence was already present from the beginning (late 19th century), the organized groups ([[Barra brava|barras bravas]]) appeared in the 1950s (barras bravas of [[Club Atlético Independiente|Independiente]], [[San Lorenzo de Almagro]], [[Club Atlético Lanús|Lanús]], [[Rosario Central]], [[Club Atlético Vélez Sarsfield|Vélez Sarsfield]], Racing, etc.) and 1960s (barras bravas of [[Club Atlético Belgrano|Belgrano]], Boca Juniors, River Plate, etc.), and continued to grow in the coming decades. With the time, every big and small football club in Argentina started to have its own corresponding barra brava, and all are violent or prepared for violence. In Argentina there are the most dangerous organized supporter groups in the world,<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,2816440_page_1,00.html |title=Archived copy |access-date=24 November 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120202124431/http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,2816440_page_1,00.html |archive-date=2 February 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and the most powerful of them are the barras bravas of [[Club Atletico Independiente|Independiente]] ([[La barra del Rojo|La Barra Del Rojo]]), [[Club Atlético Boca Juniors|Boca Juniors]] and [[Newell's Old Boys]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edant.clarin.com/diario/especiales/violenciaenelfutbol/nota1/d-07701.htm |title=Clarín digital | Deportes. River: la barra más temida |publisher=Edant.clarin.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-01}}</ref>
But this phenomenon suffered a major transformation in the late 1950s. The journalist Amílcar Romero sets 1958 as the beginning of the current barras bravas (although some had already existed since some years), with the random murder by the police of Mario Alberto Linker (a Boca Juniors supporter -not identified as such- that circumstantially was watching a match between [[Club Atlético Vélez Sársfield|Vélez Sársfield]] and River Plate at the [[Estadio José Amalfitani|José Amalfitani]] stadium), that was located in the grandstand of River Plate fans when some of them started a fight and the police burst throwing tear gas grenades, one of which hit to Linker in the chest, causing his death. Because of this murder in October 1958, the society notes the existence of this organized groups (the barras bravas). The so-called "industrialization of football" was the kickoff for this organization, because needed to control all aspects involved in the game. Before the emergence of these groups, when a team played as a visitor, was pressured by rival fans. This prompted the organization of the barras bravas in response to that pressure:
{{quote|In Argentine football, it was well established that if you played as the visiting team, you were inexorably in a tight spot. Although they were not barras bravas as we know them today, local fans would pressure you, and the police, when not looking the other way, would pressure you as well. That had to be offset by a doctrine that in the next decade became common currency: the only means by which to neutralize any effectual group with a reputation and capacity for violence, is with another, closer-knit group with as great, or greater, reputation for violence.|source=<ref>[http://www.pagina12.com.ar/diario/deportes/8-22673-2003-07-13.html The barras appear with the industrialization of the football] Página/12</ref>|sign=Amílcar Romero}}
In this way, each club began having his barra brava, which was funded by the leaders of the institution. These groups were given their tickets and paid trips to the stadium, adding later other forms of financing. But the access to these "benefits" by the barra brava depended of the hierarchy inside her. For the barra brava to be prestigious, it had to be violent, so they began to increase the number of dead.<ref>[http://edant.clarin.com/diario/especiales/violenciaenelfutbol/nota2/r-02401d.htm The origins of an evil without remedy] Clarín, especial "Violencia en el fútbol"</ref>
After the death of Linker, in Argentine football began a phase marked by "habituation" to the violence of the barras bravas, and an increase in the number of deaths. According to Amílcar Romero, between 1958 and 1985, 103 deaths related to football violence took place in Argentina, that is, an average of one every three months. However, it also clarifies that the origin of such deaths is not always confrontation in the stadium, and range from the premeditated clash between barras bravas outside the sporting venues, police repression against disorder, infighting in a barra brava or "accidents", its analysis tends to show some kind of negligence or violation of safety standards.
====1960s==== In 1964 more than 300 football fans died and another 500 were injured in [[Lima]] ([[Peru]]) in a riot during an Olympic qualifying match between Argentina and Perú on 24 May.<ref name="Disasters in soccer stadiums">{{Cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2001/WORLD/africa/05/09/soccer.chronology |title=Disasters in soccer stadiums |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date=10 May 2001 |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref> On 11 April 1967 in Argentina, before a match between [[Club Atlético Huracán|Huracán]] and Racing de Avellaneda, a Racing fan of 15 years died murdered by the Huracán barra brava<ref>[http://www.efdeportes.com/efd8/amilc83.htm The Souto case] EF Deportes</ref> at the [[Estadio Tomás Adolfo Ducó|Tomás Adolfo Ducó]] stadium. Over 70 Boca Juniors fans died in 1968 when crowds attending a [[Superclásico]] in Buenos Aires stampeded after youths threw burning paper onto the terraces and the exit (Puerta 12) was locked.<ref name="Disasters in soccer stadiums"/><ref name="clarin638336390">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.clarin.com/deportes/tragedia-entra-triste-historial_0_638336390.html |title=Un triste historial |publisher=Clarin.com |date= |accessdate=2013-09-01}}</ref><ref name="Major stadium disasters">{{Cite news|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/soccer/world/news/2000/07/09/stadium_disasters_ap/ |title=Major stadium disasters |publisher=Sportsillustrated.cnn.com |date= |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref>
====1980s==== From the 1980s and onwards, the nuclei of the biggest barras bravas began to attend the matches of the Argentina national football team in the [[FIFA World Cup]]s. That caused fights against supporters of other countries (sometimes were hooligans or [[ultras]]) and between the Argentine barras bravas themselves. Also, in the 1980s and the 1990s were recorded the highest levels of violence in the history of the Argentine football, and there was a new phenomenon: the internal fragmentation of the barras bravas. It was produced by the emergence of sub-groups with their own names inside the barras bravas. Sometimes these sub-groups fought among themselves to have the power within the barra brava to which they belonged.
An example of the violence of this years was the Roberto Basile's death. Before the start of a match between Boca Juniors and Racing in 1983 in the ''[[Estadio Alberto J. Armando|Bombonera]]'' stadium, this Racing supporter died after being pierced in the neck by a flare thrown from the Boca Juniors stand.<ref>[http://www.la-redo.net/la-bengala-perdida-15486/ The lost flare] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528143424/http://www.la-redo.net/la-bengala-perdida-15486/ |date=28 May 2010 }} La Redo</ref>
====1990s==== In 1997 a member of La Guardia Imperial (barra brava of [[Racing Club de Avellaneda|Racing de Avellaneda]]) was murdered by an Independiente supporter.<ref>[http://edant.clarin.com/diario/1997/10/08/e-05701d.htm Barrabrava jailed for the murder of another supporter] Clarín</ref>
====2000s==== In 2001, other supporter of Racing was killed, and the barra brava of Independiente was the main suspect.<ref>[http://edant.clarin.com/diario/2002/02/19/d-03401.htm Nobody is taking responsibility and today are football in Racing again] Clarín</ref> Independiente and Racing (both from the city of [[Avellaneda]], in the [[Greater Buenos Aires]]) have a huge rivalry (they form the [[Avellaneda Derby]]), the second most important in Argentina but maybe the fiercest (noteworthy that their stadiums are apart only for about 300 meters).
The next year, one fan was killed and 12 people injured, including six police officers when fans of [[Racing Club de Avellaneda]] and [[Club Atlético Independiente]] clashed in February 2002.
An Independiente fan was shot dead, and another fan was shot in the back and hospitalized when about 400 rival fans fought outside Racing Clubs [[Estadio Juan Domingo Perón]] in [[Avellaneda]] before the match. Between 70 and 80 people were arrested as a result. The match started late when Independiente fans threw a [[smoke bomb]] at Racing Club [[goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]], Gustavo Campagnuolo. That same weekend, 30 people were arrested and 10 police officers injured when fighting broke out at a match between [[Estudiantes de La Plata]] and [[Club de Gimnasia y Esgrima La Plata]] in [[La Plata]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/1826408.stm |title=AMERICAS |Football fan killed in Argentina |publisher=BBC News |date=18 February 2002 |accessdate=2010-03-24}}</ref>
A 2002 investigation into football hooliganism in [[Argentina]] stated that football violence had become a national crisis, with about 40 people murdered at football matches in the preceding ten years.
